channel.title: Words and Pictures From Old Books
channel.description: Recently added pictures scanned from old books

image.title: Words and Pictures From Old Books

item.title: Winged Mermaid from p. 199 recto, from Buch der Natur [Book of Nature] (1481), added on 14th Feb 2012
item.description:
A fifteenth-century drawing of a mermaid with wings (and breast) taken from fol. 199r of a (somewhat dubious) textbook on natural history.

The mermaid has the trunk and head of a woman, the tail of a fish, and wings, or possibly large fins.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: Strange and Fantastical Creatures, from Buch der Natur [Book of Nature] (1481), added on 13th Feb 2012
item.description:
I cannot read the text (it’s in medi√¶val German), so these descriptions are arbitrary; I’d welcome better descriptions.

Duck with head of dog

Sea-lion?

Winged two-legged horse

strange clawed bull-like thing

Merman (with tonsure) and clawed hands and feet

Dog-woman wih forked tail

Creature with top of woman and feet of bear

Winged mermaid

Winged dounble-tailed mermaid with crown

Dog with long tongue and feathered head

Dog with tusks and beard

(read more...)

item.title: He Led Her With Him, from Lucille (1882), added on 11th Feb 2012
item.description:
A man and woman in nineteenth-century dress are together on the castle battlements, in a heavily treed garden; there are mountains in the background.

(read more...)

item.description:

This is the same gate as plate 107 but from the other side, again drawn in 1732.

item.title: Scrollwork Border from page 227, from Libro Nuovo [The New Book] (1561), added on 14th Jan 2012
item.description:
This sixteenth century engraved border was made by Palatino, an engraver and calligrapher of the early sixteenth century.

See also the text with the border.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: 227.---Alphabetum Indicum., from Libro Nuovo [The New Book] (1561), added on 14th Jan 2012
item.description:
I am not sure which alphabet is intended to be depicted here.

I also made a separate image with just the scrollwork border.

(read more...)

item.title: 888.---Octagonal Border with starbursts., from New Specimen of Cast-Metal Ornaments and Wood Types (1840), added on 7th Jan 2012
item.description:
A vintage border that would look well with Christmas or holiday items.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: General Sullivan's House, from Harper's New Monthly Magazine, Vol. LXXIII. (1886), added on 23rd Dec 2011
item.description:
I thought this picture would make a good Christmas Card! It shows the New England house of a wealthy lawyer from the 18th century, snow-covered in a wintry December.

John Sullivan was a lawyer in Durham, New Hampshire. He had his own militia, and in 1774 one Paul Revere famousy rode up to his house in Durham; Sullivan raised his army along with other terrorist insurgents, and went down the river to Portsmouth, where they brutally killed the govenor of the fort there, as part of the uprising in the colonies stll known in America as a “war of independence”.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: yyy, from Pictures of old books (2003), added on 17th Dec 2011
item.description:
This atlas, shown here closed and sitting on a table, is much larger than it appears: it weighs fifty pounds! It is bound in full leather with brass to protct the corners, and with brass clasps to hold it closed.

I also took a photo of the book open to a 1664 map of the world. The book was (rather unexpectedly) in the guest lounge of a hotel in Tokyo; I do not own a copy of it.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: 893.---Border with Freemasonry Symbols., from New Specimen of Cast-Metal Ornaments and Wood Types (1840), added on 15th Dec 2011
item.description:
This border, frame, or cartouche, was on an engraved block for sale in the 1800s; it shows the sun and moon, an eye withrays coming out of it, the set-square (on the right-hand pillar) of and dividers (left) of the Masons, and a bee hive and bees (out of strength came forth sweetness, perhaps); the frame might have been used for an invitation card.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: 887.---Men Skating At Night., from New Specimen of Cast-Metal Ornaments and Wood Types (1840), added on 13th Dec 2011
item.description:
Five men are skating on a frozen pond at night, leaving trails in the ice. They smile. They are wearing top hats and eighteenth-century dress. One of them carries a cane. In the background, wintry trees.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: Nova Totius Terrarum Orbis Tabula, from Pictures of old books (2003), added on 9th Dec 2011
item.description:
Atlas open to what looks like a redrawing of Frederik de Wit’s “Nova Totius Terrarum Orbis Tabula” of 1670. The map measures over four feet on a side (1.2 x 1.8 metres), but this book has a reduced-size copy.

The book is leather-bound with brass clasps, and was a 1971 fac simile of the Atlas of the Great Elector presented in 1664 by Johann Moritz, Prince Of Nassau-Siegen, to Frederick William, Elector of Brandenburg, called the Great Elector, 1620-1688. The fac-simile itself weighed about fifty pounds and ha a wooden stand!

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: 168.---German Gothic Initials (J to Q), from Letters & Lettering: A Treatise With 200 Examples (1921), added on 15th Nov 2011
item.description:
Figures 167 to 169 show a more elaborate but an excellent and typical variety of this form of capital, which is one of the most beautiful and distinctive of Gothic letters. Shorn of its fussy small lines the main skeleton is eminently virile; and, though extremely difficult to draw, it cannot be surpassed for certain limited uses. (p. 140)

There is no letter I; use the J instead.

See also A-H for links to individual letters in the first plate.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.description:

item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: 97.---Roman Soldiers., from Old England: A Pictorial Museum (1845), added on 3rd Nov 2011
item.description:
Three Roman soldiers are shown: one with a round shield and two short spears or arrows, one with a tall shield obviously for riot control, and a long spear or javelin, and one seated on the ground.

[...] the mailed soldiers have laid down their shields and javelins (Fig. 97) to mingle in that common worship which made the Roman and the Barbarian equals.

See Fig. 91 for the full text.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: The End., from Lucille (1882), added on 15th Oct 2011
item.description:
A cold stone tomb is inscribed with the words “THE END.” A garland of flowers is draped over the tomb alnog with a quiver; a bow and a sword are in the foreground, with a cross hanging from a necklace.

It is a fitting engraving for the end of the poem and the end of the book, and I shall not spoil the story by explaining why.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: Bookplate with Crest, from The Antiquities of England and Wales (1783), added on 9th Oct 2011
item.description:
This bookplate seems to have had the owner’s name cut off, perhaps when the book was sold. It features an heraldic crest with a fleur-de-lys and a chief ermine in a bearing with a lion en passant (or rampant/) on the top.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: Costumes 1550--1580., from The National and Domestic History of England Vol 2 (1878), added on 24th Sept 2011
item.description:
A coloured print from 1878, showing how people dressed in the second half of the sixteenth century. From left to right we have:

item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: 96.---Roman Standard Bearers., from Old England: A Pictorial Museum (1845), added on 18th Sept 2011
item.description:
Two Roman men, with long curly hair and skirts, adopt feminine poses, one holding a stick with a carved eagle on it, universal symbol of despotism, and the other has a banner with SPQR, the Latin that supposedly meant “The Senate and the People of Roman” but was actally an early social networking Web site.

See Fig. 91 for text from the book referring to this picture.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)

item.title: 93.---Roman Galley., from Old England: A Pictorial Museum (1845), added on 16th Sept 2011
item.description:
An 1840s woodcut representing a Roman coin found in Britain; this coin shows a galley with cox and three (or six) oarsmen, or rowers. Counter to current practice, the rowers face forward. See Fig. 94 for an extract from the book.

(read more...)
item.author: liam@holoweb.net (Liam Quin)
